awd_titl_txt: RUI: Probing QCD with Magnetic Fields in the Multimessenger Astronomy Era
awd_abstract_narration:
There are astrophysical objects named neutron stars (NS) so dense that a single thimbleful of its inner matter would have a mass of about 100 million tons. Quite often, these stellar objects are also permeated by very large magnetic fields. A special class of neutron stars, known as magnetars, can have surface magnetic fields fifteen orders of magnitude stronger than the sun’s, and even much stronger fields in their inner cores are expected to exist. A very important goal of the nuclear theory community is to model and investigate the properties of matter under these extreme conditions. The recent observations of gravitational waves generated by neutron star mergers and the subsequent detection of gamma-ray bursts and other electromagnetic signals from the same source opened a new, very promising era of multimessenger astronomy – one that is pushing the boundaries of knowledge and understanding about the star’s composition, elements formation, and the evolution of our universe. In this multi-messenger era, observations including pulsar timing, gamma-ray bursts, and gravitational waves detection are booming, so the pressure to identify models of star composition that can explain those observations is intensifying. This project is aligned with these efforts, trying to explore the matter phases that can exist at extreme conditions like high matter density and extremely strong magnetic fields. Graduate and undergraduate students will benefit through their participation in related research tasks.

In 2015, the Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo observatories opened a new window to observe the universe through gravitational waves (GW). On August 17th, 2017, a new type of astrophysical source of GW was detected that signalized the sources as NS. NS are unique natural laboratories for investigating the physics of cold and highly dense nuclear matter beyond the capability of terrestrial experiments. Macroscopic characteristics of NS, such as masses, radii, tidal deformability, cooling, and other properties that can be measured from GW and electromagnetic observations, are related, through the star equation of state and its heat transport, to the inner matter phase of the star. In this project, the PIs will use the insight gained in previous work regarding the connection between topological condensed matter systems and cold-dense quark matter to explore some transformative ideas like a possible connection between NS and dark matter, as well as to continue expanding the understanding of quark-matter under extreme conditions.

This project advances the objectives of "Windows on the Universe: the Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics", one of the 10 Big Ideas for Future NSF Investments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to investigate the physical properties of dense quark matter phases in a magnetic field, including an inhomogeneous phase known as the Magnetic Dual Chiral Density Wave (MDCDW) phase, and probe their viability as candidates for the inner matter of neutron stars (NS), more specifically magnetars.

 

Even though the density and magnetic fields of these astrophysical objects are so large that they cannot be reproduced in any terrestrial laboratory, our work demonstrated that the properties of the MDCDW phase often resemble those of terrestrial lab materials as topological magnetic insulators. The reason behind this is that these two very different systems share some fundamental properties, like having a ground state that breaks time-inversion symmetry and having fermions with a 1+1 dimensional dynamics. These properties give rise to a nontrivial topology that manifests in the existence of an axial anomaly, anomalous electric transport, and light propagation in the medium through hybrid modes known as axion polaritons. 

 

The results of this project have provided strong evidence for the viability of the MDCDW phase as an inner phase of magnetars. Worth highlighting is the robustness of MDCDW against thermal fluctuations; the stability of the phase at temperatures several orders of magnitude higher than NSs characteristic temperatures; the overlapping of NS densities and temperatures with the parameter space where the phase is energetically favored over homogeneous chiral phases, even at subcritical coupling; and the consistency with the observed limits for the heat capacity of NS, to mention a few.

 

The fact that gamma rays entering a NS made of MDCDW matter propagate as hybridized modes of photons and phonons i.e., as axion polaritons, was used in one of the project’s published papers to provide a plausible explanation for the puzzling absence of pulsars in the center of the Milky Way, known as the missing pulsar problem.

 

In another direction, the hadron-quark phase transition at finite density in the presence of a magnetic field was investigated, considering the anisotropy of the equation of state in a magnetic field. A main result of this investigation was the development of a new framework based on the Maxwell construction, according to which the magnetic field exhibits a jump from one phase to the other. The field discontinuity between the two phases can be supported by a surface density of magnetic monopoles that accumulate at the boundary separating the two phases and boosting the field inside the quark phase. This result can help shed light on the internal structure and physical characteristics of hybrid NS with strong internal magnetic fields.

 

Considering the neutral 2SC quark color superconducting phase, it is known that at moderate densities, the Meissner masses of the electrically charged gluons (charged with respect to the rotated electromagnetism that characterizes the 2SC phase) become tachyonic. As part of this project, it was shown that in the presence of a background magnetic field, such a chromomagnetic instability gives rise to the restructuring of the ground state through the formation of charged gluons vortices. These vortices can significantly boost the initial background magnetic field. Therefore, an NS with a core made of this quark matter phase and with a seed magnetic field of 108 G generated by the common dynamo-effect mechanism could have vortex-boosted fields as large as 1017 G in the star interior. This mechanism may explain why magnetars can exhibit much stronger magnetic fields than ordinary NS. The requirement for this is that magnetars have a neutral 2SC color superconducting quark phase.

 

This award served to train students at all levels with great success. During the duration of the award, two doctoral students completed and defended their dissertations and are now postdoctoral fellows elsewhere. A third PhD student is in his first year at the UTRGV PhD program. An MS student supported by the award was a coauthor on one of the project’s refereed papers and received the “Best MS Physics Thesis Award” from the College of Sciences. After graduation, he got a job in the high-tech industry in Brazil. This research project also supported the training of six undergraduate students. Overall, this project contributed to the education of several members of under-represented groups in physics. Specifically, all the undergraduate participants were Hispanics, and three were female.
